description.text:
Needed an X-carriage for my E3D V6 but wanted to keep my drag chain. Loved ThingiRob's modular design (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1438795), but it didn't have a cable chain attachment. So I remixed it using TinkerCAD and this thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2038198. Took me a couple of hours since I'm a novice.

Big props to the designers on whose shoulders I stand to bring you this thing..

title: Open Top Cradle for GoPro Hero 4

description.text:
This so far is the most complex thing I have designed from scratch.
I had a need which was that Most GoPro mounts have a door or screw you have to open or undo to get the camera out, this usually means disassembling the rig entirely just to get the footage or replace the battery. This solves that problem (I was inspired by Devin from Make Anything who did a similar project for an older GoPro). Not having a top or door means the GoPro can just be lifted out of the rig and easily placed back in at will! And the best part is if you have a permanent rig set up on your 3D printer for time lapses, your shots will always look the same! This rig also keeps the back open to allow access to the screen on the hero 4 silver model and the side open to allow access to the micro SD card and for the camera to be plugged in without removing it. I'm really proud of this and if you make one I would really appreciate it if you posted a picture in the "I made one tab!"

Printer:

Cocoon Create 3D

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100%

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I printed mine upside down

Post printing you should just be able to remove the supports and have no more cleanup. It should work straight away.
Side note- I'm unsure as to whether this will work for the other Hero 4 versions as I only have a Silver, and thus have only tested it on a Silver. But I see no reason why it shouldn't fit as the only major physical difference between models is the screen.

I grabbed a pair of calipers and first actually modeled out a 1:1 scale of my GoPro in Autodesk Fusion 360, once I had a that I created a box on the X & Y axis at the bottom of the GoPro model that was 2.5mm wider and longer than the GoPro, once that was done I extruded down the Z axis 2.5mm to create a base and extruded up the Z axis 15.00mm to create what would become the walls. On the outer edges I made a 4mm Chamfer and then on toe top I created a Shell Cut to creat walls 2.00mm thick (allowing for 5mm between the GoPro and the cradle, this should create a snug fit). Then I just cut out holes in the walls for anything I wanted to access such as the front power/mode button and the screen on the back.
Last step, I just created and extruded the little mount pieces on the bottom of the cradle!
(This is probably not a very good explanation but I wanted to put something here in case people wanted to try and create something themselves)

description.text:
These back plates are part of a multi-thing universal upgrade system for Rigidbot Big printers. See the other thing uploads required to complete it as linked below.

These back plates are for upgrading a Rigidbot Big (RBB) with a ReliaBuild 3D (RBB3) 24V ATX style power supply and the new cool running super quiet main board with the 2oz full area heat sink. This two piece upgrade system needs to be printed on a Rigidbot Big printer with a 12" x 16" bed.

Note that the power supply mounting space is moved over toward the center by about 3" to allow for the power supply cables to reach the main board without the extensions required by the three part universal system. Use the tall riser part for use with the new locking cable LCD so that the cable can still reach without the adapter.

This system requires the removal of the lower back bar on the printer frame and insertion of the feet extension and anchors in the corner knuckles. You can find the feet and anchor files in the Regular back plate upgrade system with pictures of the installation here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1712645/#files

The main board cover can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1850924
or here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172691
Which one you select depends on if you have the I2C add-on board for the Skip-Sense auto skip correction system.

As these are precision fit parts it is highly recommended that you use calibrated filament using the system found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

Printer:

Rigidbot Big

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

24%

Notes:

Print the first layer slow at about 30mm/sec. To keep the parts from warping I start with a bed temp of 60C and at 0.5mm of height or 4 layers I turn it down to 45C. Cooling fan comes on 30% for the second layer and is on full when the bed temp drops. 3M blue painters tape on a stock bed cleaned with Windex sticks really well and will not peel up.

Assembly Instructions

Pre-thread the main board side with M3 bolts to make it easier to put the two parts together. Connect the two halves together before mounting the power supply and the main board.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Project details and more info here.

A realistic unicorn skull, according to the evolutionary biology textbooks I referenced.

This looks fantastic printed in white filament, and even better cleaned up and painted. If you have access to a metal printer (or care to pay for it), I highly recommend that.

I can't take credit for the scan of an actual horse skull, but it required heavy cleanup and editing.

I've included here the entire unicorn skull, as well as the horse skull and unicorn horn as separate files. I've had more luck printing the skull in two parts and bonding post-process.

Use and enjoy!

Sources:
Adafruit's 3D Printed Unicorn Horn
Marchal Geoffrey's 3D scan of a horse skull via Sketchfab

author: julcoh

description.text:
A bit of a twist on the traditional spinner
Not as much weight on the outside (although you could glue on some marbles or steel balls)
But, it does spin quite well since it slices through the air
Uses a standard 608 bearing in the center

Since joining Thingiverse, I kept adding items to the "Things to Make" collection, not realizing that there doesn't seem to be a feature to move an item from one collection to another at a later time.

It seems the only way is to visit the thing's page and collect it again so you can choose a collection for it to go into, then go into the original collection, edit it, remove the item, etc.

So, being a software developer, I decided to write a "Bookmarklet" to automate performing these actions.

To install the Bookmarklet, just go to the Thing Files and click on the Bookmarklet.htm, and just drag and drop the "Collection Manager v1.1" link to your Favorites Bar.

Then you can just click the Bookmarklet on the Favorites Bar to activate it.

The Bookmarklet uses JavaScript to create dialog within the Thingiverse page, and then uses Ajax calls to get your collection and item names, and to call the URLs that create collections and collect and remove items.

I have tested this in Chrome and Internet Explorer 11 on PC and it works great for me.

I spent quite a few hours developing this, so I hope others find it useful as well and any tips would be greatly appreciated. Thanks!

title: Metal Slug Tank V2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Updates:

  • 2.19.18 - Added SLA/DLP versions for printing as a whole. You can re-chop this for FDM as well but the tracks will need to be reinforced. Files are marked - *.SLA.

  • 10.4.17 - Updated all the files especially the tracks. I added an insert between the tracks to make them a true solid and yet retain the look of the original split. I prefer the print the version laying flat vs the vertical V2 split (which works well too but lots of support to clean off). For your printer, you will need to enable supports and then clean between the tracks easily with a X-Acto. Gun mounts now have the proper pin to go to the machine guns. The top hull has 2 versions one with and without the machine gun mounts. It's up to you to print whichever version you'd like. Also, the MG, you will need to print 2 of them but given the delicate barrels, you're better off faking them using stretched filament and gluing them on. 8% scale of the original model is about 3 inches which is very small. You will probably want to go 10 - 12%. 15% being as large as your hand.

Update 9.18.17 - Added new splits to help with printing.
Update 5.8.17 - added final drive retention axels to hold the drive wheels better to the chassis - SPLIT TANK ONLY for now.

Yet another Metal Slug tank. This model prints very nicely split. It is broken into the tank body, the guns and muffler and the gun mounts. Bottom fenders are split too. Scale to your desired size and print it.

You will need to scale all parts to an equal percentage. I should have done this but decided to let you decide the size of your print.

Print at 100 microns with support. SUPPORT IS NEEDED for the tracks!!!!

Original artwork from: http://3dmag.org

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100 microns

Infill:

10%+

Notes:

Test your filament temp to reduce stringing. I am printing this at 198 C and 1.1mm retraction. My print is about 3 inches long or at 8% scale of my files. I will try a larger print with more retraction.

Need to fix my Replicator 2X and get PVA support filament. You will find cleaning out the support from the tracks is a job for tweezers.

Brake Safe Monitor Adapter for LC200 Sahara 2017. This adapter fits in the space used by the card holder and requires an RM6000 "Brake Safe" (Monitor) to complete the installation.
Brake Safe monitor is used to check the battery condition when towing a trailer which has electric brakes.

After printing the attached adapter....
Step 1) Remove the top case from RM6000
Step 2) Remove the lower dash from drivers side and remove switch panel & card holder assembly.
Step 3) Slide the RM6000 lower half (with circuit board) into to adapter from the front.
Step 4) 2 x M3 x 25mm screws & nylocs to hold assembly together
Step 5) Insert Brake Safe front panel (blue label) into provided slot
Step 6) Insert assembled adapter into switch panel (from behind) with 2 screws.
Note: some trimming / filing may be necessary for a snug fit.
Step 7) Re-install switch panel, dash & test.

Detailed installation instructions may be found on the LCool forum
http://www.lcool.org/forum/viewtopic.php?t=44496 (membership required)
search for "RM6000, BrakeSafe & Card Holder".

This is the second in my line of Bot-Shoppe robots. This robot is a single-armed heavy lifter. He has one arm and an offset head for a nice, asymmetrical design.  
Printed in multiple parts, the STL files contain the suggested colors. But of course you can print them however you like.  
This robot has a ball-jointed shoulder to allow you to glue it in almost any position, and two alternate hands, one with two fingers, and one with three, for your preference.  
You can see by the photos that it scales well. It was originally meant for the smaller scale and stands just over an inch tall. But printed at 2x, it is just as nice or nicer.

Grab-Bot is made using a similar aesthetic to Tread-Bot. He has organic shapes for his body and head, but more mechanical shapes in other areas. The juxtaposition of the two makes for an interesting design.  
He is designed to be glued together. There are no moving parts.

author: Buzzerbro

title: ReliaBuild 3D Extruder Carriage Mounted Limit Switch System

description.text:
This is an extruder mounted X limit switch system for the ReliaBuild 3D printer that is backwards compatible with the Rigidbot (RB1, RBB) printers. It allows for the removal of the limit switch mount on the rear X carriage rod and the use of the shorter limit switch cable connected to the extruder PCB.

The "Switch Trip" file marked with RB1 is for the steel frame Rigidbots. The "Switch Trip" file marked with RB3 is for the Aluminum frame ReliaBuild 3D printers. They are not interchangeable if you want a good tight fit. There is a hole in the bracket that can be used to secure it to the rail. If printed with calibrated filament the bracket is tight enough to not need a bolt to hold it in place. I recommend one be used anyway. Skip-Sense enabled RB3 and RBB3 printers will have a threaded hole already in place on the X-Z rail. RB1 printers with a steel frames will need to have a hole drilled and tapped for an M4 bolt. The hole is in line with the rod connector on the other side. The rod connector can be used as a guide for locating the hole. If you use a 1/8" drill you can use an M4 bolt to self tap the hole.

The "Limit Switch RB1" file is for mounting an RB1 style limit switch where it points to the side of the PCB. If you drill the holes all the way through it will mount an RB3 style switch which bolts on from the top side. The "Limit Switch RB2" file is for mounting an RB2 style limit switch where it point straight up from the PCB. These files mount on the extruder carriage with bolts that replace the rear left bearing mount bolts using M3-14mm bolts (same bolts used for the main board mount on an RB2 or RB3). These are the switch holders that should be used on a Dual head carriage. They will work on a single mount carriage but will put the nozzle very close to the bed bolts.

If you have a single extruder setup and want a little more clearance then use the RB2 Single and RB1 RB3 Single designs. These put 2mm's more of clearance between the nozzle and the bed leveling bolts. The holes for mounting an RB1 or RB3 style limit switch are already all the way through on this design. They have a lower profile to help distinguish the difference between the two configurations.

As these are precision fit parts it is highly recommended that you use calibrated filament using the system found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1037301

I (or someone) lost the blind brackets for our blinds during the office move.
So for fun I made some that work fine for me.
I have included the SketchUp files if you would like to modify them.
One has a hole only and the other has a square peg and a round hole. Enjoy

The brackets have little winglets to help the ABS from lifting off the heat bed these break off with ease.
I used .4mm extruder, 3 shells, .2 layer with 70% infill.
I increased the temp of the ABS until it was a bit shinny but not burnt,
this seems to make a stronger part for me.
I use 5% PVA (wood glue) mixed with water dabbed on with bit of rag to an warm IKEA mirror tile that is clipped onto the heat bed .
The Aluminum tape on the printer is to stop some static problems I was having.

title: MP Select Mini V2 40mm Fan Duct

description.text:
The 2017 revision of the Monoprice Mini Select has a new hotend, so fan ducts designed for the original MPMS will not fit. This model is broadly inspired by FDM_Guru's 40mm fan mount, but with a completely different and smoother duct design. There is a lot of room for tweaking.

This clips onto the MPMS V2 hotend using the stock spring clips. It may or may not fit on the original. (It looks like the vertical distance from the clip to the bed is unchanged, but I don't know if it'llAll you need is a 40mm fan. (I just used twist ties...) You might consider printing just the first few layers and then checking that your mounting hardware will fit in the provided holes. A Fusion 360 file is provided that you can edit.

This can be printed without supports. Due to the proximity to the hotend and nozzle, something heat-resistant should be used. I printed in PETG, which seems to go well.

Printer:

MP Mini Select V2

author: conklech

description.text:
Read instructions. You'll need double-sided tape, a Pilot G-2 pen, and a rubber band. May work with other pens and printers as well. Installation: http://youtu.be/hPhRbs8RJQA Operation: http://youtu.be/EYAUOTS33PM With a proper config, you can make Slic3r and Pronterface think they are printing out a thin one to two-layer object when instead you have a spring-loaded pen tied to the printer with a few offsets.
Otherwise, feel free to use any proprietary plotting software that has a "lift-Z" feature.

To make the constant-force pen (refer to the picture with the three pens):

  • Obtain a Pilot G-2 pen.

  • Take pen apart and remove the spring and rubber molded grip from the front/bottom housing. All you'll want to keep for this project is the ink cartridge and plastic front housing.

  • Tie or tape a rubber band to the top end of the ink cartridge with a generous loop hanging toward the tip.

  • Insert the ink cartridge into the front housing.

  • Tie or tape the loose/hanging end of the rubber band to the upper portion of the lower housing (near the threads). Remove any slack if necessary. The ink cartridge should be able to travel up the housing a few mm when a proper writing force is applied and spring back down when released.
    • Attaching pen holder to printer (refer to picture and "installation" video):

  • Clip constant-force pen into newly printed holder. If it is loose, build it up with a layer or two of tape and try again. It should fit snugly and not ride vertically.

  • Cut a piece of double sided tape for the back of the printed pen holder.

  • With the pen in the holder, affix the assembly onto the flat side of your Huxley's "X" axis carriage so that the pen's tip sits roughly 5mm below the height of the nozzle.

  • Ensure the tape is firmly set and the constant-force pen you made snaps in and out just fine.
    • Offsets and Misc. settings in Slic3r (only for finely extruded vector-graphics (SVGs). Go ahead and experiment):
    Y = +32mm
    Z = +5mm
    X = 0mm "Nozzle diameter" = 0.1mm
    "Lift-Z" = 5mm
    "Minimum travel after retraction" = 0.5mm Bed temp = 24C
    Nozzle temp = 24C (First)Layer height = 0.075mm - 0.1mm
    Perimeters = 2
    Solid layers (top/bottom) = 0/0
    Detect thin walls = yes
    Infill%(pattern) = anything you want, some look cooler for specific purposes. Notes:
    I recommend you use Pronterface if you use this 'SVG to finely extruded STL' method because it will prevent cold extrusions. By saying this "SVG to finely extruded STL method" I mean an STL vector graphic that was extruded out to roughly one or two layer heights and printed as if it were a one or two-layer plastic part (though with pen attached and offset).

remixed_from.author: ScribbleJ
remixed_from.title: Parametric Herringbone Gear Set for Stepper Extruders

description.text:
Attempting to build add on automation for my Velux skylight. Requires a NEAM 17 Stepper Motor. I've tested this with my extruder motor which is a Kaysan
http://www.kysanelectronics.com/Products/Detail.php?recordID=7850 Posting the STL files here, the scad files can be found on github. https://github.com/krbaker/3dprinting/tree/master/velux-automation

print one of each part.  Also requires an 8mm allen wrench for the drive.  
Put the small gear on the NEMA stepper and use a 3mm set screw to keep it in place.  You'll have to guess exactly where on the shaft it goes, mine is just about flush with the end.  
Put the top onto the mount and use 4 x 3mm screws to hold it together.  leave the screws just flush with the top. Put the NEMA 17 stepper face down onto the top mount plate so the gear sticks through the hole.  
put the screws from the velux crank through the two mounting holes, put the spacer on that.  Check the orientation of the ridges in the skylight, make the spacer plate match, add the space to the stack.  put the screws all the way through the mount and the spacer.  
Put the big gear into the slot.  Push the 8mm Allen key through the hole in the top plate, gear and then mounting plate.  Screw the mounting plate onto the skylight using a screwdriver going through the top plate and gear.  You'll have to rotate the gear to access the screws.  Also note you might want to open the window to a mid position so that you have freedom to move the gear in both directions.  
I'm sure this voids your warranty.  I can't take any responsibility for damage you do to your window or anything else for that matter.

description.text:
Shakes-Bot is the fourth in my line of Bot Shoppe robots. Shakes-Bot is a writing automaton. Again, mixing organic form with mechanical shapes, Shakes-Bot is my latest creation in robotic play writing.  
His single arm is a ball-joint, so you can pose the shoulder at almost any angle. If you do not glue the ruffle, it can be spun for a bit of fun.  
Why one arm? Well, this creation was commissioned by my high-school-teacher wife who teaches Shakespeare and all of her colleagues wanted one too, so I had to print a bunch. One of her friends asked why he had one arm, then paused, then replied to herself: I guess he only needs the one.  
Enjoy Shakes-Bot. If he's popular, perhaps he can be accompanied by Emily Dickins-Bot.

author: mksteffensen

description.text:
Update 20/09/2017

After many hours of use (it's used daily as a work tool) and 4, 5 revisions I'm uploading the latest version I've come up with. Each step just tweaks the original design based on my experience with practical day to day use of the holster.

It's now shorter, less clunky, allows Surge to stick out at the bottom while still fitting snugly. Top "locking" design is still work in progress, the shape and indents are literally in spaces where my tool has gouged out tracks from frequent use, so I'm trying to reflect this in it's design.

Enjoy!

====

I have seen the feedback about newer (latest?) version of Surge not quite fitting in, being a little larger, I can't verify the sizes since my tool is by now few years old and apparently replaced with newer model. You may need to scale up the print by few % if it's too tight.

====

A remix of an older design, designed it from ground up based on the original model.

I got inspired to create my own design after printing out the original - only to realise that it wouldn't fit on my 50mm wide work belt :)

It's been used for weeks now, works flawlessly in my case, tool clips in place and stays put, still easy to get it out when needed.

description.text:
This is 2k/4k 5.5 '' LCD 3D printer project for high speed printing.
Semiautomatic leveling of the build plate.
LCD cooling system.
LCD screen protection by default by the printer design.
Equalizing of the air pressure of the both lcd sides to reduce the vacuum forces.
Size without PSU 300x300x428mm (XYZ).
Build area 119x66x155mm (XYZ).

Needed things and order of assembly:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X185ppNmLT8&list=PL0jXMDcb7_SD23YF-uyGPE94NsETmnMbk
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL0jXMDcb7_SD23YF-uyGPE94NsETmnMbk

CAD file (AutoCad 2013+ format) for CNC and laser cutting included.
Example BOM list(MS Excel format) with links included.
***Designed for outside PSU - do not put it inside - it will brake the air flow and cooling.

Site of the project: http://www.dkt3dprinters.com/

Any tips and donations are welcome. Thank You in advance.

27.05.2017 Some updates:

  • Added +0.5 mm on each side of the 3 mm alu buildplate piece;
  • Couldn`t find 5 mm LED plexiglass in my country (only 3 mm), so Plexi cover has been reworked for 3 mm panels;
  • M3 bolts for plexiglass cover and its 2 hinges should be changed from 12 mm to 10 mm, but it is not big deal if You don`t ;) ;
  • Added + 10 mm to small MDF sheet for LC and + 10 mm on each side for the bigger one,
    because of the company, that I am using for laser cutting;
  • Made some simple handle for plexi cover;
  • LC and CNC files - updated and reuploaded;
  • The hole for M5 bolt on the 5 mm alu piece should be with thread, if not - make it 5.5 mm and use second M5 nut;
  • The hole for the M8 bolt on the 3 mm alu holder for the build plate should be threaded. Use some super glue for the bolt.

28.05.2017 More additional info:
Additional drilling is (obviously) needed to MDF panels assembly. Use 2.4 mm drill or enought pressure to tighten the screw directly without drilling.
Steel plate it good to be paint in satin or even better mate color.
All printed parts, which receive direct light from the LED array should be printed in red, green or orange color filament.

31.05.2017
So... LED Plexi is not very suitable(too dark - almost no transparency). Bought some green fluorescent molten plexi - close to twice the price of LED one... ~20$ for the piece needed for LC.
BOM list file reuploaded with more precise prices.

02.06.2017
Some new pictures of:

  • All small 3d printed parts (ABS printed);
  • Steel plate + 2 small steel pieces + all nuts, bolts, washers;
  • Inside panels;
  • Drawer;
  • Front and side panels;
  • Back panel stuff;
  • Comparison with my small and my Delta printer ;) .
    Did not use full proper order of assembly. Just wanted to check the construction - so far everything fits as expected.

TRENDi Delta Maker; TRENDi MiniBot

No

No

20-30%

description.text:
I simplified the mesh using MeshLab (500k faces to ~10k faces) and removed the rooster's comb to make it look more like a hen.  
The model does need support to print properly. The default settings in Cura Worked For Me(tm).

comments.text: I had no trouble printing it without support - I did my hens at 50% and 25% of the size, and also some ancient version of slic3r.  No trouble with slicing.  I find that differing versions of slic3r will slice an object and some will not..  I can tell you our version of slic3r if you are interested.
comments.author: nerdhaus

comments.text:
There's a lot of other factors that would help/hinder printing without support. I did eventually get it sliced and printed (I believe I used Cura) with supports, and it printed fine, and the supports were pretty easy to remove.
That said, increasing line width and/or decreasing size should both improve the ability to print without support. I don't think there's anywhere on the model that would absolutely require support (i.e., any unsupported protrusions that aren't overhangs or bridges).

description.text:
This is a remix of 2ROBOTGUY's penny fidget spinner. The only change I made is that I added a 0.5mm top layer to each of the penny slots so that the pennies can be fully encased inside the spinner.

Instructions: I sliced the spinner using Cura 2.5 and then used GCode Simulator to visualize the layers from the gcode. Then I opened the gcode and added an M600 command (pause) just before the layer where the hole for the pennies is closed.

When printing, the printer should pause once the penny slots are done. Add 4 pennies to each slot (which should be even height with the top of the spinner at this point) and resume the printer. It should perfectly seal in the 4 pennies.

I use these bearings from Amazon.

Remixed with Tinkercad: https://tinkercad.com/things/dwgSh8iOmyE

author: Bertone84

description.text:
Summary

This is a project about building and controlling a Plate Saw Machine. The whole projekt can be found at the following Git-Hub Link: "https://github.com/VirToReal/VirToCut".
YouTube-Video: https://youtu.be/xQ6T13urcc0

What is this?

This is a Plate Saw Machine, which cuts straight stripes from a plate. The machine can be controlled via Software automatically, or trough the software/control-panel manually. The cutting-distance of the saw blade and the material feed can be controlled, too. The thickness of the saw blade will be added automatically in manual-mode.

To control the saw via software in automatic-mode, you can use a code syntax i developed for this machine which will look like that:

A50 B300 // Feed Material 50mm and cut into that material 300mm.
A50 B300
A30 B300
A30 B300
A10 B300
ROTATE // Saw stops, user have to rotate the plate 90°, some visual assistance shows user which stripes have to be placed into the machine (not ready yet) and confirms via software/hardware- button.
A100 B100
A100 B100
WAIT // Saw stops, user have to place a new pair of stripes into the machine and confirms to proceed.
A80 B60
A80 B60
WAIT // Saw stops, user have to place a new pair of stripes into the machine and confirms to proceed.
A50 B20
A50 B20
A50 B20

The result can be seen the graphic I made in the gallery above. To press the plate on the workbench, I constructed a structure which do this for you if you select the right material from a drop-down menu.

Generating dynamical Structures

You can generate your own components by using the "ConstructionTemplate.scad"-File with OpenSCAD (http://www.openscad.org). Every component are adjustable in their dimensions as described in the “OpenScadDokumentation”-Folder. In OpenSCAD you also able to switch between the complete overview as the picture below and each single printable part as listened in the “OpenScadDokumentation”-Folder by using the “printmode”-Variable within the “ConstructionTemplate.scad”-File. All details are described in the file itself.

Necessary Skills

To get this project to work, you need some experience in printing parts with a 3D-Printer. Also some knowledge in electrical engineering are required, because you have to make a PCB and wire up a power-supply, raspberry-pi and an arduino-mega-2560 + ramps-shield. My files for milling/etching the PCB are to be found in the "KiCad"-Folder. The Files can be edited with the KiCad-Software (http://kicad-pcb.org). I used FlatCam (http://flatcam.org) to mill the "Gerber"-Files from KiCad.

Software

I use Python to send G-Code-Commands from the Raspberry-Pi to the Arduino over a serial interface. Marlin (http://marlinfw.org) is running on the Arduino and interprets the received G-Code-Commands and drives the engines with the RAMPS1.4 Shield (http://reprap.org/wiki/RAMPS_1.4). My Marlin-Configuration can be found in the "Marlin Firmware"-Folder.

The Python-Software can be found in the "Python Software"-Folder. At the moment its only available in German. If its necessary, I will rewrite it in english, too. But feel free to make a Fork ;-). The Software is already able to generate saw-pattern-templates, to cut a plate in different sized plates automatically.

TODO

But consider, the project is not fully completed yet. Some smaller improvements still has to be made:

  • Structure on the material feeder, which prevents the material from rotating. Thought on something like a feather tensioned clamp.

  • Some smaller software updates (don't find the right time at the moment).

    Any help would be appreciated.

description.text:
This is a case designed only for a GBS-8200 video converter board, if you want to use it for GBS-8220 then you need to modify provided files to include additional hole for second VGA connector. This is possible as also IGES files are included within the project.

The bottom half features cooling vents, holes for all external connectors and the power connector and mounting pads with holes for the board.

The top cover features cooling vents for processor, buttons holes and GBS name/logo. Top cover can be just snapped on bottom half without use of any screws or movable latches.

Bottom and top covers need to be prined with supports.
Buttons are designed to be printed without slicer-generated supports.

Buttons and main body/bottom should be printed in their default orientation as in the model files. Print the top cover in upside-down orientation.

You need to print:

  • the bottom "main body" part,
  • the "top cover" part,
  • four times "button" part.

Assembly instructions:

  • take bottom part and insert GBS board inside, fasten the board using screws (it is possible that you have to drill bolt holes to appropriate diameter of your screws).
  • take top cover and insert four buttons into button holes in the cover, these should move freely inside holes (depends on your print quality it is possible that you need to remove all imperfections inside holes, this can be done manualy with usage of a sharp drill)
  • snap on the top cover on bottom part

Printer:

XYZPrinting da Vinci Junior

No

Yes

0.2

15%

  • printed with PLA
  • nozzle diameter of 0.4mm
  • thick shells

• adjust screw holes diameter
  • clean button holes inside from all imperfections

description.text:
WARNING: THIS 3D PRINTED NEEDLE DISPOSAL SYSTEM SHOULD ONLY BE USED BY HEALTHCARE INSTITUTIONS AFTER CAREFUL EVALUATION AND TESTING. USERS ASSUME ALL RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE SYSTEM'S USE.

DESCRIPTION:

This is a needle disposal system designed to fit repurposed HDPE plastic containers with 35mm outside diameter, 5mm spaced threading. The design requires a tether which can be custom-made or use a simple twist tie.

50+ of these systems are currently in use at a local children's hospital after several months of evaluation, testing, and design iterations.

Some of the images are of older versions with a single notch for detaching needles from syringes. The STL file features two notches.

USE:

The inner cap fits onto the bottle's threading. It has two notches on either side to catch and assist in removing a needle from a syringe. Once the needle is inside the bottle, the outer cap is fitted on top using two more securing notches to keep the bottle closed until its next use.

A tether is used to keep the outer cap nearby the inner cap when in use. Repurposed HDPE bottles with their original caps can be sealed and disposed of according to a healthcare institution's guidelines and the 3D printed system can be reused with another repurposed bottle.

The SketchUp file is included, and contains incremental models showing how the threading was created.

Also included are labels that can be printed out and used on repurposed HDPE plastic containers to designate them clearly as sharps disposal containers.

READ MORE:

This project is part of our medical maker initiative. Read more here: http://www.progressth.org/2017/01/medical-maker-project-continues.html

description.text:
I have experimented with designing folding frames before, with questionable success :) This one finally works as i wanted.

Designed to fit around the scisky, be robust, and quick and easy to print; and it does the job pretty well. It's light (less than 6 grams), doesn't need any screws, everything snaps together nicely if your printer is properly calibrated.

I use a rubber band to hold the battery below the body; the latest version even have grooves to keep the loops nice and even, and protect the FPV transmitter and camera on the top at the same time. In a crash the arms tend to fold in, absorbing the hit; i had a prop pop off once.
The arms are for 8.5x20mm motors and 50-60mm props.

Print two of both the straight and the bent arm, don't forget to mirror the bent one, although they works upside down too, just look a bit "off" :)
I've also included the first body design; it's simpler and tougher but it blocked the USB port so had to take it apart every time i wanted to tune my PIDs. The new one is fine.

Enjoy!

Notes:

I printed with a raft because the filament i was using is some made in China ($6/kg) cheapo PLA which likes to warp if the base is anything solid and larger than a few cm X a few cm

and I suppose, faily certainly, you dont need a raft if you are printing with any PLA which isnt garbage.

I filled the bottom 2cm of the box with soft clay and stick the bits in it and let the soft clay dry and set.

description.text:
Here you have my pieces for 4xidraw plotter (PLOTTER_LSM). You can see my tutorial on my youtube's VideosCalculoElectronica, or looking for LSM plotter and more.
Here comes 13 pieces, design even for low quality 3d printing. They are solid and strong. I hope you enjoy them, good luckl!

Para los que entienden lo que estoy poniendo ahora mismo: Aquí os dejo las piezas del 4xidraw que he rediseñado. Son más resistentes, preparadas para ser imprimidas por cualquier impresora 3D aunque no sea muy buena. Las medidas (para las varillas) coinciden con las de 4xidraw. Solo cambié mucho la parte que levanta el bolígrafo, haciendo más ancha la medida entre varillitas. CUidado con esa parte, no se podrían mezclar con las piezas del 4xidraw. El resto, sí. Mucha suerte!. Podeis ver tutoriales de montaje y uso del plotter e instalación del software en mi canal de youtube VideosCalculoElectronica. Nos vemos!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Steel

With FreeCAD

I used FreeCAD for all this pieces, copying them from 4xidraw models. But, the part I most worked is the pen holder and carriag, changing the width of the little bars. Take care about that.

comments.text:
Hecho!!!! Funcionando. Me ha sido muy útil tu info y tu tutorial para generar el Gcode con la extension del laser.
Pero va muy lento en comparacion con otros videos que he visto. Sabes si se puede cambiar la velocidad y como? Gracias
comments.author: Chocarrat

comments.text:
La velocidad se controla desde varios parámetros.
Desde el plugin, pones la velocidad de trazado con Laser Speed, máx a 4000, y la de movimiento sin pintar a 10000 (Travel Speed).
Luego, en el GRBL de nuestro Arduino, puedes modificar los parametros MAx rate de cada eje. Yo , a 5000, me va muy rápido.
Eso se ve mandando al Arduino un $$, y v eras creo que es $100 y $101, qeu son los max rate de los ejes X e Y (el Z es otro tema).
Espero qeu te sirva. Igualmente, la aceleracion tambien influye ($120 y 121??)
comments.author: Chocarrat

comments.text:
Hecho!!!! Lo he hecho desde el Gcodesender (GrblController) y muy fácil. al principio un poco de lio pues alteré los pasos por mm y la lié parda, pero en el wiki vi como resetear los valores. A mi a 10.000 mm me va bien aunque mis varillas no son muy buenas y hace un poco de ruido. Hice una prueba a 20.000 mm pero ya era demasiado (fallos en el dibujo). En cualquier caso me quedo embobado viéndolo trabajar. Hace años tuve un plotter calcomp en el estudio (antes de la época del chorro de tinta) y era una preciosidad. Lo regalé a un instituto y ahora me arrepiento.
Mil gracias por los consejos y por tus excelentes vídeos. Han sido el complemento perfecto para la info de Misan.

A mi el software me daba problemas, e, indagando, encontré este otro plugin, alque no tenia que añadir Python ni etc. Va igual de bien, y es más comodo de instalar. Las piezas las diseñe para qeu fueran comatibles con as de MISAN (menos las bases , quizas, si pusieras una de cada tipo no encajarían, tendría que ser a pares, pero todas están pensadas para eso. title: Improved recycled spools dresser, double, containers & drawer with spacers

description.text:
This is a remix of Recycled spools dresser. I like so much this idea, but I need to improve it. After first printing I need separator or boxes where i can put small screws or dices, whitout making them mixing. So I've drawer the follow solution to improve intelligent space in every drawer.I've created 3 different solution to improve this idea:

1- Standard dresser (file called "Standard")
for this I've create 3 different boxes: Standard 1-2, Standard 1-4 and Standard 1-8 (it indicate box dimension: half of dresser, quarter of dresser and eighth of dresser)

2- Half Standard dresser (file called "Half Standard")
this dresser change height of dresser (is half of Standard dresser) for this I've create 3 different boxes: Half Standard 1-2, Half Standard 1-4 and Half Standard 1-8 (it indicate box dimension: half of dresser, quarter of dresser and eighth of dresser)

3- Separator Drawer and Drawer Separator: different concept, same thing: a standard dresser with hole for separator: you can put or remove it every time you need, to expand or reduce a section.

This design is from DANILO COVA from Como (Italy), one of the great Makers of our Community. He found the way not to trow away his used spools from FILOALFA - 3D filaments Italian producer - and re use them as desk organizer to store screws, bolts, small parts.
This simple and creative idea is so good that we decided to share it with you. Maybe you don't use this producer's filaments, but you can easily modify the design to fit the kind of spool you usually buy. Use some self-tapping screw to mount the drawers inside the spool.

IMPORTANT: you don't need to make holes in the spools, simply use the pre-existing holes near to the edge to insert the screws.
All the best!

title: Dark Souls The Board Game Card organizer

description.text:
I support the Dark Souls - The Board Game kickstarter kampagne and just got the copy of my game. My aim was to make a organizer for the cards and beeing able to close the box completly (OCD and so on).
This part is not a remix of the design by entropy86 - I just wanted to add his source for alle the people who don't want to use zip-lock bags and don't mind if the box isn't closed completly.

The included card-holder-thingy is really crappy, once you open the packages. So I designed two holders for the different card sizes.

One is for the bigger boss card. The other one isfor the loot and encounter cards (you will need two of those). I put all the tokens and dice in a zip-lock back.

author: hein4bloed

description.text: Not tested already to pot the led on side of the printer.

I bought some time ago on a Chinese webstore three housings for Arduino Mega. I have one Mega and two Due's. The measurements of the PCB and the drill holes are the same for both. Unfortunately the case didn't fit the Due, the pins on top and the usb-ports were different. (Original housing with Mega is also a photo added.) So I used only the bottom for some time which was sufficient.

In a creative mood I decided to make the rest of the housing myself. The housing is made of 3 mm plexiglass (PMMA). Just like the original make of clear transparent acryl. The box wat cut using a 60 W laser cutter. The PCB is fastened with M2.5 screws and nuts. The case is held together with the original screws and nuts of the original housing, M2 x 18mm.

author: Printerforever

description.text:
Very great thanks to ggenter to inspire me with his "Synology DS216PLAY Vibration Damper". I used it to dampen my Prusa i3 MK2 but i recognized quickly that the unsymmetrical weight distribution of the printer was not compatible with the one kind of damper.

Because the printer is heavier in the back we need stiffer springs there and some softer in the front. Furthermore we have to consider that the power distribution unit on the back right side is the heaviest corner.

In order to that i reworked the damper and made it to a parametrical model with variable wall thickness.

By trying out different settings I am now by the following distribution:

Front: 1,1mm Spring
Back right: 1,2mm
Back left: 1,1mm

I have noticed that the spring got squeezed after a time in fact of permament weight support. If thats the case just replace the concernong spring with one a step stiffer.

Hope you like it. In my case it killed noisy vibrations almost absolutly. I now only hear the fan.

title: Calliper brackets for high precision printer calibration
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I designed a set of 3 brackets that can solidly attach my calliper to the frame of my Mendel Prism 1.5. The advantage of that is reliability and repeatability of the measurements. It all worked so well that I would need to hunt down a more precise calliper to be able to calibrate further. YES I am saying that I have reached the limits of my calliper which is 0.01 mm. I did about 3 runs of calibration on each axis to get there. Kudos to Josef Prusa for his awesome reprap calculator. At some point you may see that the new esteps values makes your steppers overshoot, I averaged that estep value with the previous one that didn't overshoot and that got me right on the spot.

Basicly you use those to attach a calliper parallel to your axis's or to your filament. It allows you to calibrate your esteps for the axis and the extruder. I strongly suggest your visit my blog here for a proper explanation: http://gearforge.blogspot.ca/2014/01/3d-printer-axis-calibration-how-to-do.html *Note: the bracket to attach the calliper on top of your printer (above the extruder is missing, my bad i lost the files) but you will most likely all have to redesign your own brackets since your printer is most likely not a Mendel Prism. Were a rare breed. This was really posted to teach others how precision calibration is achieved, not provide a pre made solution for each printers out there.

author: thecrazy

print_settings.Notes:: The lid may need supports - we printed it with the bearing cavity face down and the printer coped fine bridging the bearing cavity. YMMV.

description.text:
This is a small electric touch-plate for auto-probing the Z-height for a CNC machine. It's designed for the MPCNC with a common "Chinese" spindle. I think it should work on any hobby CNC, although the spindle-mounted electrode might need replacing with a clip.

It is designed to screw down (M6 holes at 10cm spacing) onto a CNC work-bed. It uses a small piece of plain copper PCB board from Maplin (35x40mm) as the touch-plate, and a 608 bearing with a wire soldered to it as the spindle contact. This spindle has an M8 smooth shaft protruding from the top, and the bearing fits perfectly.

The design is in three parts: the base, which is normally screwed down; the top, which pins the copper board in place; and the lid, which fits on top and holds the bearing. It's designed so that the lid sits on top of the copper touch-plate to prevent dirt and dust build-up (which might affect connectivity), and to make it impossible to use without attaching the spindle electrode.

Originally, the top, which screws onto the base with 4xM3 10mm bolts, was intended to be screwed down hard to hold the copper plate in place. But we were worried that the cutting bit, repeatedly touching the plate, might dent and damage it. So we took it off, cut up a pair of small springs, and placed them under the board as shown and fitted the top so that the copper plate would depress a mm or so under pressure. It turns out that the touching action is actually very gentle.

More details soon...

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The lid may need supports - we printed it with the bearing cavity face down and the printer coped fine bridging the bearing cavity. YMMV.

Interfacing to a RAMPS board

We've wired it into the Z-Min end-stop connection on a RAMPS1.4 control board. We're using Marlin 1.1.0RC8, and z-probing works successfully. More notes to follow on configuring Marlin. Once configured, the following GCode worked to create the calibration sequence shown here: https://www.youtube.com/embed/QCCdA6yrZwA 

G0 X0 Y0 Z30 F2000
M0 S1
G38.2 Z-50
G92 Z12.4
G0 Z30 F1000
G0 X50 F2000
G0 Z0 F1500
M0 S3
G0 Z30

The vital bits are: the G38.2 performs the probe itself (to a maximum depth of 50mm), and the G92 Z12.4 sets that point to be 12.4mm, which we had measured as the height offset of the device. After that, the G0 Z0 F1500 demonstrates that Z0 is at the base-board height.

title: Arc Reactor Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ironman arc reactor fidget spinner.

It is designed to work with a 26mm outer diameter and a 10mm inner diameter bearing. I know this is not a standard bearing size but its the only bearings i had lying around. if you are interested in one that fits a standard size bearing leave me a comment and if there is enough interest i will make one.

Building instructions:

parts list:
26mm OD and 10mm ID bearing
20mm long m3 bolt x1
copper wire and 36 resistors are not essential these are just for aesthetics.
3d printed parts

You will need to print:
base x 1
bearing spacer x 1
top&bottom x 2
coil x 10

Assembly instructions:
Glue the 10 coils onto the base and push the bearing spacer into the bearing and then clip the bearing into the base. The m3 bolt is used to align the top and bottom with the centre of the bearing spacer after they are glued the bolt can be removed. When you are finished you can add the wire to the coils and resistors or any other parts as you see fit.

As always if you have any questions or ideas on how to improve this project please comment or send me a message.

title: Lasercut 10mm MDF Armor Basing
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are truly niche but I've posted them anyway, in case they can be re-purposed for your own gaming needs. My experiment with custom MDF basing for my growing collection 10mm or 1/150 scale armor (http://www.thingiverse.com/search?q=m_bergman&sa=). Sized as a compromise with the scale I choose for my collection and the counter sizes recommended for Canadian Wargamers Group Great Battles of WWII series found @ https://canuckwargamer.wordpress.com/. I know it's one of the great debates for any armor collection but I have not yet decided whether or not I will be basing my armor? Produces plenty of bases per sheet with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 24" x 18" (Arch C) sheet, the size that fits across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. And if you download this, please LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

description.text: Mount for PX4Flow. Will sit 10mm below mount plate.

I have an off brand Chinese hot air/solder station (a Hakko knockoff from Circuit Specialists). While putting up a shelf, I broke the axle of the solder spool. Although I could have glued the center back together, one of the end caps just went missing so I made some measurements and just printed a new one.

Print all three pieces. If your bottom is "squishy" you may have to open the bottom part of the tube out with a hobby knife. If you get carried away (don't ask how I know) a little glue will save the day. But if your printer is lined up right the top part should just pressure fit with one of the caps.  
The picture shows the red printed pieces and the black original pieces that were copied.

title: Parabolic Chess Set
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Chess set built mostly of parabolas.

Designed using OpenSCAD with a generic parabola function that defines a polygon based on input width and height.

STL files are scaled in inches to print a pawn with a 1"x1" base and the pieces with a 1.25"x1.25" base.

One scad file lays out all of the pieces on a chess board. The other one is scaled and arranges the pieces onto a circular area for printing.

description.text:
Voila un petit objet permettant de moins répendre de laque sur votre machine quand vous en mettez sur le plateau. A utiliser en complément de cartons ou feuilles de papier pour camoufler les alentours de votre machine!
Réalisé pour model de laque "L'oreal infinium" (voir photos)
Pour l'utilisation, faire toucher l'avant sur le plateau, puis déposer la laque de droite aà gauche tout en avançant. Le reflux est dirigé vers l'arrière et sur les cotés...
Pour ceux qui voudront encore moins de reflux, autre méthode: poser à plat contre le plateau, rester appuyé, puis étaler par la suite avec une spatule.
S'imprime dans le sens de la première photo (base du cône à plat sur le plateau)

title: Jinx Fishbones - Split in half for easier printing

description.text:
Jinx's fishbones

This is a remix of Jinx Shark Gun by NenZilla, the only real difference is that the model was split in two simmetrical halves and I made the shark's mouth only partially hollow to avoid the need for supports.

Of course keep in mind that neither me or NenZilla own the design of Jinx's Fishbones since Jinx and all of her assets are property of Riot Games.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.08mm

Infill:

10% or higher

Notes:

I attempted the print two times with 100% and 160% scale (the one you see pictured) and it prints just fine. There may be some hollow spots on the surface, but it may be related to my printer and they are not noticeable and easily filled.

Clean up the two halves and sand them to be completely flush

After the printing is done, clean up the edges with sandpaper and a file if needed. Also if needed, use sandpaper to make sure that the two halves are as flush as possible (especially if you printed in ABS).

Glue the two halves

Using your favourite kind of glue (Acetone works great for ABS) stick the two halves together.

Clean up the seams

If the seams are very noticeable, you can fill them with some kind of 3D printing filler. I personally used ABS+Acetone juice, which does a pretty fine job. A bit of sandpaper may help to make the seams as "seamless" as possible.

title: Panasonic N2QAYB00057210302A Remote Control Battery Cover

description.text:
Panasonic N2QAYB00057210302A Remote Control Battery Cover

This is a battery cover for the above-named remote control. Ours broke when it was dropped on the floor, and we have an older 3D TV which is difficult to control with generic controllers; the original manufacturer's part sells for about £50 in the UK so that was my motivation for this design. Also, I wanted to learn FreeCad having previously been an OpenSCAD user.

I flipped the STL of the cover 180 degrees before slicing and printing.

Status (Important)

This isn't finished item but the first one I did which clicked in and didn't fall out (or break the clip). You'd be better off buying a new battery cover (if you can find one) or a new remote control (if you are quite rich).

I'd encourage you to download the FreeCad file and improve the design. It's the first time I've used this application, so if you wouldn't mind sending me your improvements I'd be greatly obliged.

The photographs are of a draft-printed component (0.2mm z-step, higher speeds) so it's a bit rough. The marking on the bottom reminds me I really should replace the tape on the bed.

To Do

The photographs show the most urgent modifications:

  • The cover is almost 1mm too short.
  • The triangular section used to make the cut at the clip end of the cover doesn't match up with the actual control (which is very curvy in almost all dimensions and a nightmare for the novice FreeCad user!).
  • The clip could be a bit thinner, especially if printed in something a bit more bendy than PLA so it won't crack when pulled back.

History

22nd May 2017: Freecad file edits: made cover 1.2mm longer (freecad file only); adjusted clips -- now slightly bigger for more positive closure. STL file still old version.

I recently decided to rework my K8200 3D-Printer for using GT2 timing belts instead of the original T5 versions. For this I needed to design new clamps for fixing the ends of the belts to X and Y tables and I planned to do this with integrated length adjustment for belt tension.
I also needed to consider the lower diameter of the 20 teeth pulleys compared with the original T5 wheels. Result were the model files included to this project upload.
I originally thought I could use the original mounting brackets for the reverse rollers, but this was not correct. Unfortunately I already disassembled my printer when discovering that. Therefore I needed to mill new wheel mounts instead of printing those parts. Nevertheless I added the models of those parts to the project because it still may be printable and usable with some rework.
You may ask if it was worth to spend that much time for improving the belt drives. I’m actually not completely sure. The printer runs more smoothly and the printing results look better, but only very very little. The resulting dimensions are also more accurate than before. Therefore I would say it depends if you want to achieve perfect results and if you don’t hesitate effort to get to that point.

title: Micro Drone Propeller Thrust Testing Jig (8520 Coreless Motor)

description.text:
This is a small test jig I made in order to measure the level of thrust generated by 3d-printed propellers.

Check the pictures for a general idea of how the thing comes assembled. I used a few M8 bolts, washers and nuts to hold the main assembly. The smaller screws are all M3.

The motor holder houses the 8520 coreless motor.

At the base of the arm I used two SMR63ZZ bearings that allow the arm to pivot easily.

The scale I use is from Kenex. It's an older model, but you can find the equivalent at this link.

When the thing is fully assembled, rest the arm with the long M3 screw (assembled on the "needle" part) on the scale and if the scale is on, simply hit "tare" before running any tests.

Included you will find a few pictures of the final assembly, along with the STL files and SLDPRT files (in case you wish to modify the jig to suit your needs).

The hub is where you can mount the propeller prototype. All you need to remember is to add a 3mm hole at the center of your propeller in order to secure it to the testing jig (I used an M3x10 screw for this purpose).

You will need one of each part printed, aside from the main holder and the bearing holder.
The bearing holder (triangle-like thing) should be printed in 2 copies. The large hole houses the small bearing and the other two holes secure it to the arm using M3 screws.

The main holder should be printed in 3 copies. You can go for more for extra stability, but 3 should be the minimum copies for this assembly.

I remember running into a few issues with the hub, so you should scale it up and down if you cannot install it on the motor shaft. This depends quite a bit on your printer and its cooling capabilities. The motor shaft is 1mm in diameter, so you'll need to play around with your settings to get the hub nice and snug.

Once fully assembled, I recommend setting the whole thing on some vibration dampening surface. I used a piece of dark packaging foam which seems to hold well. Make sure the screws are tight in your assembly, since at higher RPMs the M8 nuts can come loose due to vibration. You can also use split washers or lock nuts.

Tevo Tarantula

comments.text:
Fair enough.
Based on what I see, I would say the force applied by the lever is 2 times the actual force produced by the propeller (sorry :)
You have to tcalculate the ratio of the distances (distance to motor/distance to arm pushing on scale) and divide your measurement by that factor.
comments.author: emanuelbucsa

comments.text: I guess you're right. Thinking about it, I can see the "needle" is just half way of the pillar, implicitly the measured force is about half. From the 51 propellers made and tested thus far, I think that they can provide sufficient lift as-is with a minimally designed drone. Would have to do a bit of math and check that the weight of the whole contraption doesn't surpass the lifting capabilities of the sum of all the propellers.

title: ANET A8 Corner bracket / surface mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Corner mounting bracket for anet a8:

  • allows mounting the frame to a rigid surface (e.g. 18mm plywood or similar surface) with common screws.
  • forces the acrylic frame sections into alignment at 90° to the M8 rods during assembly for smoother Y axis travel.
  • adds rigidity to the frame and pulls front of y axis down to prevent lifting during aggressive jerk.
  • 6 used on the example here (rear and both sides of front box section).
  • works with existing popular front and rear braces by other users for Y axis tensioners.
  • if already assembled, unassembled the M8 rods one at a time to make it easier.

Use something like a cross head self tapping no.4 (4mm diameter) x 1 1/2" screw (dependant on surface thickness) for mounting, tighten screw fully down (shown loose on image) into the countersunk hole to compress the bracket to the surface.

Printer:

anet a8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

40 %

Notes:
  • add a 4mm brim to help stabilise the part during printing.
  • print orientation as per photo for best strength.
  • import the stl twice and mirror one copy in cura to make a left and right handed pair.
  • if your print settings are little rough, drill through the section for the M8 rod with an 8mm bit.

description.text:
Ive been abit irritated over the stuff that are for Iphones lately, so i figured out i would make something for Samsung S7, or samsung in general. So i joined the fun.

This is a monocle adapter or a Lens adapter for any binocular thats got the diameter of 30mm. The hole on this adapter is 29.5mm. It makes for a tight fit and its hanging greatly there. You get some great distance photography with a cellphone with this addon adapter.

You do get the circle around the picture but ive found the quality depending on the monocle or lens added for use with this adapter with phone.

The Gcode already contains the input needed for an Anet A8 3dPrinter.

title: AC inlet / cover for Mean Well LRS-350

description.text:
Note: the picture I posted of my own cover is the version 1 prototype, and has a gap between the cover and the top cover of the supply, exposing the screw terminals. The attached STL and SCAD files (version 2) have the front edge of the cover raised up 10mm, and completely covers the screw terminals. I could have printed off another bracket, but just covered up the gap with electrical tape instead.

I've been recommending the Mean Well LRS-350 power supply as a low cost, safe/reliable replacement for the cheap/questionable "S-240" power supply that comes on the Anet A8. Here's an inlet/cover together that makes using it a bit easier.

The power supply slides into the cover, and is held onto the supply with a pair of M4 x 6mm flat head screws that screw into the side mounting holes of the supply. There's one "DC outlet" hole on the rear of the cover, which aligns with a hole in the frame of the A8.

This cover holds the typical snap-in, fused/switched IEC inlet module that you can find all over eBay and aliexpress. Before you snap it into the cover, solder and heatshrink (highly recommended) all of the required AC wiring onto the IEC inlet, because once you snap the inlet into the cover it will be extremely difficult to remove, and very hard to get at the solder joints with an iron.

This design uses about 75 grams of filament when printed with 30% infill and a 1mm outer shell, but believe me the extra plastic is worth it. The cover feels solid, and doesn't bend or warp when you're plugging/unplugging the AC cable.

Use this bracket to mount the supply to the A8: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2172223

Printer:

Anet A8

No

Yes

0.2mm

30%

I sliced this in Cura, because the supports it generates are much better than slic3r's.

title: Nema 17 Linear Actuator - controlled by ESP32 Wifi Webgui
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Update20170509 Detailed build instructions :- https://hackaday.io/project/21883-nema17-3d-printed-linear-actuator-esp32-webgui
This is a Linear Actuator (250mm+ stroke) using a Nema17 Stepper motor and Ramps driver.
The Actuator is controlled by its own Wifi WebGui using an ESP32 Wifi module, so is easily remotely internet connected.
The Actuator will easily lift a dead weight of 2Kilogrammes .... not tested any more than that yet.
Video of it in action :-
https://youtu.be/G30edgY6RIA

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm (for screw parts) rest 0.15mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

When printing the lead screw segments. be sure to blow plenty of air to set the rising screw quickly... print slow and easy.

Building it up

The actuator needs 4x M3 screw rods as the main support column.
The actuator needs also 3x5.5mm carbon fibre / or equivalent slider rods that connect to the end effector.
The actuator also requires 2x 608 skate bearings

Body shell support screw Carbon slide rods Generic 608 skate bearings Walkthrough and testing of the Actuator... with 1.5Kg dead weaight test ESP32 The Web Gui courtesy of ESP32

author: Chiprobot

print_settings.Notes:: You may need to fine tune the object scale depending on how well setup your printer is, in order to get a good shaft fit. If its too tight scale by 1.01, if too loose, scale by 0.99, etc.

description.text:
Temp and mode selection knob for GM HVAC panel on the following vehicles:

CHEVROLET BLAZER 1995-1997
CHEVROLET S10 PICKUP 1994-1997
GMC JIMMY 1995-1997
GMC SONOMA 1994-1997
OLDSMOBILE BRAVADA 1996-1997

These have a very small D shaft and the mode selection requires quite a bit of torque for the shaft size, so the OEM polycarbonate knobs like to crack and break regularly.

These may get loose fairly quickly depending on the material you use. I will design and upload a version that will accept the metal insert, and hopefully those will last longer.

The pointer features a hole to allow back-light through at night when printed with non translucent filament. I will upload a different pointer style for translucents once i get some trans filament to experiment with.

This is a work in progress!

Printer:

Flyingbear P902

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-30%

Notes:

Flip the model upside down in slicer so that the knob handle is facing the bed, and support from bed only. This will leave a "supported structure" finish on the face of the knob, which i don't mind. But you you don't like that you can split the knob in 2 and glue it together, which I don't recommend for accuracy reasons. The OD radius is 20.25mm for those that want to flip it on its side and "cut off bottom" to make 2 haves.

You may need to fine tune the object scale depending on how well setup your printer is, in order to get a good shaft fit. If its too tight scale by 1.01, if too loose, scale by 0.99, etc.
You can vapor bath this part if printed in ABS for a nice appearance, just plug the shaft hole so it doesn't distort.
Brushless motor grip / pliers for 2205 motors. Print with flexible material.
